Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The three colleges of Seattle Community College (SCC) District VI are awarding 170 scholarships of up to $6,000 each over a 5-year period to talented, low-income students pursuing careers or transfer associate degrees in astronomy, biology, botany, chemistry, computer science, engineering, environmental sciences, geology, mathematics, nanotechnology, oceanography, physics and sustainable agriculture. This ONSIGHT Collaborative Scholarship Project began at Seattle Central Community College, and therefore the new collaboration between the Seattle Central, Seattle North, and Seattle South Community College campuses relies on and is building upon established and successful scholarship procedures, student support infrastructures, undergraduate research programs, the previous experience of the management team on Central's project, and the powerful collaboration of three Science and Mathematics Divisions across the district. The Seattle Community Colleges serve highly diverse populations. Central alone serves the largest number of underrepresented students of any of the 34 colleges in Washington State. Recent records show that over one-half of the potential ONSIGHT Collaborative scholarship appplicant pool consists of women, over 30% are first generation, over 43% are students of color and over a third reside in households in the lowest two socio-economic quintiles. Thus the recruitment and selection processes, and the mentoring and support service structures established for the ONSIGHT Collaborative Scholarship project are designed to support the significant participation and success of scholars typically underrepresented in STEM fields. The project's evaluation plan is contributing to the base of S-STEM knowledge regarding student support interventions and their correlated impacts; dissemination of success and lessons learned to local and national audiences is providing information for replication. The project is transformative due to the necessary collaboration between the three Science and Mathematics Divisions: deans, faculty, student support service personnel and scholars are meeting and working together frequently to assure student success. Situated within one of the great science and technology centers of the nation, the Seattle Community College District finds that there is no better focus to exercise the benefits of collaboration than by working together in support of its up-and-coming STEM students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our S-STEM (Scholarships-Science Technology Engineering Math) grant was designed to support talented, economically disadvantaged STEM students by providing scholarships, academic and career supports, and opportunities to engage in STEM-related activities. Over six years, we supported 69 individual community college students with scholarships of up to $2000/quarter, depending on financial need. Of those, 56 scholars completed their degree or transferred to a 4-year institution, five remain at Seattle Central College in pursuit of their AS degree, two transferred to other 2-year institutions where they continue to pursue their AS degree, one left due to health-related reasons, two left the college for unknown reasons, and three were dropped from the S-STEM program due to poor academic performance. Of those, one remains a STEM student pursuing their AS degree.

Our S-STEM scholars completed and transferred at higher rates than STEM students college-wide. While we do not have institutional data to compare all STEM students to our S-STEM scholars, we can compare completion and transfer rates for a cohort of students beginning Fall 2013 and ending December 2015. Completion and transfer rates for STEM students over this period was 54% and 32% respectively, while completion and transfer rates were both 91% for S-STEM scholars. All S-STEM scholars who completed also transferred to a 4-year institution to complete their BA or BS degree.

Reduction of financial burden may have contributed to the higher transfer rate of S-STEM scholars. When asked specifically whether the scholarship allowed students to reduce the number of hours spent working, and therefore not studying, 44 of 48 respondents (~92%) said that it did. The remaining four students were forced to continue working in order to maintain health benefits or to maintain the cost of living in Seattle.

Participation in a variety of STEM-focused activities may also have contributed to the higher completion and transfer rates of S-STEM scholars. All S-STEM scholars met with a faculty mentor at least twice per quarter, and participated in a variety of additional STEM-focused activities, including STEM-specific academic planning and transfer workshops, a STEM speaker series, field-trips to local STEM-businesses and non-profits, and opportunities to complete capstone projects. Some of these activities were available to all STEM students, whether they received an S-STEM scholarship or not. While we were not able to track the participation level of all STEM students, we were able to do so for a large subset who participated in a related grant which offered the same activities. In any given quarter, our S-STEM scholars participated in 2.7 STEM activities, while these other STEM students participated in 1.8. STEM students not involved in either of these grants participated in fewer. S-STEM scholars reported that these events helped to increase their sense of belonging to the STEM community, see themselves as future STEM professionals, build confidence in their STEM abilities, and to provide encouragement. For some or all of these reasons, the number of events attended may have led to the high completion and transfer rates observed.

Largely in response to S-STEM scholar feedback, our institution is attempting to institutionalize the most effective and well-liked practices that were tested during this grant. Mentoring, the STEM speaker series, academic planning and transfer workshops, and opportunities to complete capstone projects were are cited by students as contributing to their sense of STEM-belonging. We are currently working to acquire the consistent financial resources and personnel needed to institutionalize each of these.


Last Modified: 11/01/2016
Modified by: Joshua Whorley

While we do not have institutional data to compare all STEM students to our S-STEM scholars, we can compare completion and transfer rates for a cohort of students beginning Fall 2013 and ending December 2015.
